title: 107_s495
content: The Act titled "Tax Equity for School Teachers Act of 2001" allows for a deduction for professional development expenses and classroom supplies of elementary and secondary school teachers. The Tax Equity for School Teachers Act of 2001 allows eligible teachers to deduct qualified professional development expenses and classroom supplies under section 162 of the Internal Revenue Code. The Tax Equity for School Teachers Act of 2001 permits eligible teachers to deduct qualified professional development expenses for tuition, fees, books, supplies, equipment, and transportation required for enrollment in a qualified course of instruction directly related to their teaching curriculum. The Tax Equity for School Teachers Act of 2001 allows eligible teachers to enhance their understanding of State standards and provide instruction on teaching children with different learning styles and discipline methods. The Tax Equity for School Teachers Act of 2001 emphasizes the importance of disciplining children in the classroom, early interventions for struggling students, alignment with state standards, effective programs to improve academic achievement, and professional development for teachers. The Tax Equity for School Teachers Act of 2001 emphasizes professional development approved by local educational agencies to further educational goals. Qualified elementary and secondary education expenses include books, supplies, and computer equipment. The Tax Equity for School Teachers Act of 2001 defines eligible teachers as those working full-time in kindergarten through grade 12 classrooms, including instructors, counselors, aides, and principals. It includes provisions for funding professional development, books, supplies, computer equipment, and other materials used in the classroom. The amendments made by the Tax Equity for School Teachers Act of 2001 apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000.
